Problem:
Let us consider a system governed by the equation \\(z' = i \omega z\\) where \\(z\\) is a complex function of time, \\(t\\), and \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit, and \\(\omega\\) is a real constant frequency. An external operator applies a transformation \\(T(z) = z e^{i \theta t}\\), where \\(\theta\\) is a constant real shift in frequency.

If the initial condition \\(z_0\\) at \\(t=0\\) undergoes the transformation \\(T(z)\\), and thereafter evolves according to the system's rules without further transformation, will the state \\(z(t)\\) at any later time \\(t=T\\) be the same as if the transformation was not applied?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\(T(z)\\) modifies the initial condition to \\(z_0 e^{i \theta t}\\). It alters the system's frequency from \\(\omega\\) to \\(\omega + \theta\\), thus affecting the solution path over time. At any later time \\(T\\), the state will be different as it oscillates at a modified frequency.
